instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.820-2850A: What is 820-2850A? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SDA: What is SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SDA? SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SDA is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED..
definitions.R5280: What is R5280? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.R5281: What is R5281? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont charge
threads.message:
Hi customer brought back a board i fixed the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> on. [url]https://www.rossmanngroup.com/boards/forum/board-repair-troubleshooting/13473-solved-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-shorted-out-on-the-<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>/page2[/url]

I retested the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>  

pin 1 - 4.1v 
pin 2 - 4.47v
f7040 - 12.3v 
<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> res 27/28 - 21.3 ohms
17/18 3.1 ohms

Is this the isl again? and what would likely cause it to go out again? 
thanks 
nate

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont charge
threads.message:
12.3V means SMC doesn't work correctly...
Do you get green light on magsafe?
Check battery bus lines to ground and voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont charge
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is present??? If yes, this is a bad SMC.... Was this water damage in the first place??? Apply some flux and heat to see if it come back to life...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont charge
threads.message: It is a data bus issue. Could be battery/ISL/SMC/battery indicator. Anything connected to <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_BSA</SIGNAL> is suspect.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont charge
threads.message:
okay iv narrowed it down to the <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SDA</SIGNAL>. voltage there is varying from 115v up to 350v over and over.

im getting a solid 12v on the <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR>. so is this the isl because im not 100% sure if the <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> goes directly to the isl..

Also now wile i was testing near the isl the charger light has gone from green to nothing. but now im getting 114v on <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> after the green light stopped working.

threads.message: yeah same thing i was thinking.  now that my green light is gone, i checked the probe for  <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SDA</SIGNAL> and now im getting a solid 96mv.  also the board wont power on anymore.  i was testing voltage near the <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> when the green light went off.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont charge
threads.message: 350V will kill you if you touch it! No idea what is going on there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont charge
threads.message:
Stop using auto-range.
Use cheap multimeter in 20V scale, avoid any missunderstood this way...
Post <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and 3V42 values now; voltages and resistance to ground too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont charge
threads.message: It seems like you have a short to chase on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. My guess is shorted <TRANSISTOR>Q7535</TRANSISTOR>/<TRANSISTOR>Q7530</TRANSISTOR>. Inject 1v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, try and find what gets hot. I feel like full story is missing here, first you went from it turning on but SMBUS issue where SMC couldn't tell ISl what voltage to set, now it's dead...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont charge
threads.message:
3v42s @3.3v
3v42@ 1 ohm
This can't be real...
I hope you don't measure resistance to ground with power...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont charge
threads.message: I missed that. I'm glad we have our newly registered puppy to correct me. Your measurements make no sense and are fucked. I can't give you advice until measurements start to make sense again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont charge
threads.message:
[USER="1"]larossmann[/USER] okay i figured i had a short on the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. i'm not sure what i did to make it dead but im pretty sure i must have shorted something together when i was testing voltage. this board came in from a customer who was changing his battery left a screwdriver on the board that was on the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and got the think pretty dang hot he said. i replaced the isl and all was good but not long after it stopped working not sure what happened.

Im aware that these mesurments are not making sense also, but im getting these readouts so im hoping this things is not fucked hahah.

if i cycle through the range options its showing me .99 ohms to 1 ohm. not sure why im getting 1 ohm..

[USER="682"]2informaticos[/USER] of course im not testing with power.

Update: i tested 3v42 on the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> im getting 0.8 ohms to ground and a solid 3.39v with power. i double check the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and im getting close to 1v not that thats any better. the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> if i set the meter to 0L. k it will give 160 ohms dropping, and normal setting shows 0.
im not sure whats wrong or (what im doing wrong) but i could take a video of the test for oversight.

<RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> pin 2 @0.03v 
<RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> pin 2 @0.09v  these are not within  there 5% range if i understand correctly not sure that they have any importance right now but just adding to the info. 

BTW Thanks for taking the time to help me in my struggles here! much love!

im not sure why i'm getting 1 ohm with proper voltage so i'm wondering if this may have something to do with things not working.

i also should note that when the green light stopped coming on when i'm guessing i shorted something together next the the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, it also fried the power i/o and when i was testing other boards i noticed this and swapped it out for a new one. i dont know if that helps shed any light on things, (i forgot to mention this in the intro)

k

If I ask you for a kilo of cocaine, how much cocaine am I asking for?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont charge
threads.message:
k is 1000's. 

a kilo is 2.2lbs....

or 989 ohms of resistance. so its actually correct.  i adjusted my settings and im getting o ohms. i mis understood the thousand for  thousandths.  clearly a big mistake on my part.  Thank you very very much for helping me understand this!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont charge
threads.message:
BTW we use diode scale to measure resistance to ground.
Again, forget the auto-range option!!!
Use one multimeter in 20V scale, for voltages.
Other one on diode scale (same as buzzer on many meters)...
You don't need a Fluke meter; a 10 bucks chinese meter works good for what we need.
